en: Interview with Leslie Wereszczak, 2019-12-13

Interview with Leslie Wereszczak, small animal ICU supervisor for the UT College of Veterinary Medicine. Wereszczak discusses the treatment of victims from the fire, particularly cats. This includes the management of their pain as well as dressing burns mostly located on their footpads and faces.
 This is a representative quote from the interview: "It was something that we never saw coming, and I don't know how we made it through that month. I really don't, but we did. It definitely changed me, for the good."

Interview with Leslie Wereszczak, small animal ICU supervisor for the UT College of Veterinary Medicine. Wereszczak discusses the treatment of victims from the fire, particularly cats. This includes the management of their pain as well as dressing burns mostly located on their footpads and faces.
 This is a representative quote from the interview: "It was something that we never saw coming, and I don't know how we made it through that month. I really don't, but we did. It definitely changed me, for the good."

Interview with Leslie Wereszczak, 2019-12-13
Interview Questions
Could you share with us your background and how you got involved with UT?
Did you have any sense about the fires and what was going to come?
Did you have any experience with prior disasters?
Can you describe a typical day for you?
What kinds of animals do you usually treat?
Were there any responses to your initial social media post?
When did you get the first indication that you would be receiving patients?
Are there any facilities similar to UT nearby that could offer aid?
Is it part of the first responders protocol to look for animals?
You also volunteered at a MASH like shelter in Gatlinburg?
About how long after the icident were you volunteering at this shelter?
Were you volunteering before or after the first patients arrived at UT?
Can you tell us about the animals you received, the first ones you received and the types of injuries and animals you were treating?
Did you have prior experience with burn victims earlier in your career?
Can you tell us about Topper, the cat that received a lot of media attention?
How long after Topper sustained his injuries did he receive treatment? Had he been on his own for some time?
Did Topper go to a triage unit after being found by first responders?
How many cats were treated at UT? How many survived?
Were all the cats reunited with their owners?
Do you keep up with any of the cats? How are they doing?
You were pioneering burn treatments for animals during this time?
What does wound debridement mean?
What caused the animals to have facial burns?
What caused the animals to have facial burns?
Can you tell us about the pigs that survived through the fire?
Have there been networks develop about treating burn victims?
Can you talk more about the specialties different team members bring to treatment?
How large is the nursing staff?
Did you find yourself working overtime during this time?
How long was the period of intense activity?
Does the turnaround time speak to the quality of care provided by the staff?
Was this expensive and how were those costs managed?
Are there ways in which the unit has changed how it operates since then?
Have you had any burn patients since then?
Was there any suffering from smoke inhalation?
Do the animals seemed to have healed from the emotional trauma?
Any observation about the social work team?
Is the social work team part of the hospital? How large is it?
Is there anything else that you would like to touch on?

 This is a representative quote from the interview: "It was something that we never saw coming, and I don't know how we made it through that month. I really don't, but we did. It definitely changed me, for the good."
